Articles.Content: I am running a stock game. Do I need to backup anything else besides the saves folder?

The saves folder oughta do it.

But bear in mind that KSP doesn't have any DRM on it, and disk space is pretty cheap these days.  So the simplest thing to do is to just copy the entire KSP game folder to a new location before the reinstall-- then you're guaranteed that you have a pre-reinstall, playable copy that is untouched.

(That technique can also be handy when KSP does a major update-- for example, if you copy your 1.1.3 install to a separate folder, then when it updates to 1.2 automatically via Steam or whatever, you'll have two separate installations of two separate versions, and you can play whichever one you want.)
I actually tried to use verify local cache, but that didn't fix the issue. Does verify cache "fix" any wrong engine values?

By "verify local cache", you mean the Steam thing, yes?

I believe that what it does is something like this:

  • It has an idea of what the "footprint" of your game is supposed to look like:  i.e. what files, located in what folders, with a "fingerprint" of what each file's content is supposed to be.
  • If there are any files that are supposed to be there, but are missing, it downloads a fresh copy of the file and puts it in the right place.
  • If there are any files that are present, but altered from their "fresh install" state, it spots that the fingerprints don't match, so it downloads a fresh copy and overwrites the local copy.
  • If there are any "extra" files that it doesn't know about, then it just leaves them in place and ignores them.

I've only had occasion to use it once, when I accidentally overwrote a stock texture file (silly goof on my part, where I did a move instead of a copy, so I was tinkering with the original).  Used the Steam feature, and it worked like a charm, fixed it right up.

Can you provide a bit more context?  From your original post, I didn't get that you're having some kind of technical problem, but this comment of yours,

3 hours ago, Jestersage said:

"fix" any wrong engine values

makes me think you're having some sort of problem.  What's the issue?  What do you mean by "wrong engine values"?
Well, I am not sure, but for some reason the actual performance of some ships and engines are worse than I remember. I may have muck around the parts folder, but AFAIK I have modified anything...

18 hours ago, Jestersage said:

Well, I am not sure, but for some reason the actual performance of some ships and engines are worse than I remember.

One thing to bear in mind, if you're coming back to KSP after a long absence:  In 1.0, one of the big changes that happened was engine Isp curves, plus they changed the effect of Isp reduction in atmosphere (used to mean "increased fuel consumption"; now means "lower thrust").

In particular:  certain engines are now classified as "vacuum engines" and have absolutely terrible performance at sea level.  That is, if you try to use them on the launch pad, they'll still gobble the full amount of fuel, but will produce practically no thrust and will have trouble even getting off the launch pad.

It's not a bug.  It's a deliberate design feature of the game.

Some of these vacuum engines include:

  • Terrier
  • Poodle
  • Rhino

(that's not a complete list)

...You can spot a "vacuum engine" in the vehicle editor by looking at the Isp display on the part info window.  Every engine should show two Isp numbers, one for vacuum and one for ASL (i.e. sea level).  The "vacuum engines" have really horribly low ASL Isp.

So, don't use them on the launch pad.  Use them on upper stages only.

Note that "vacuum" doesn't have to mean 100% vacuum.  You don't have to get all the way to space before you use them.  Even at fairly low altitudes, like 10 km, the atmospheric pressure is only a small fraction of sea-level pressure.  So you can use them at relatively low altitudes, just not down on the ground.  A general rule of thumb:  over 10 km is okay, below is not.
Yeah, was trying to use the biggest SRB to launch a 3 person capsule with a little fuel, ala Ares I.
